title: Before 30 March 2019, what will happen next with regard to the UK's notification of Article 50?
possible_answers: It will be revoked by the UK
It will be extended by the UK and the European Council
Neither of the above will occur and the UK will leave the EU
correct_answer: It will be extended by the UK and the European Council

This final prediction is based on the question not resolving until Parliament accepts the extension date but AND enacts May's deal.
In this case this question becomes 
1) UK revokes Article 50, pure and simple, 2016 referendum IS NOT honored.
2) The May deal is enacted, UK leaves the EU with a deal.
3) May deal fails leading to no deal Brexit, aka known as hard Brexit or crashing out of EU.
4) May deal fails and both UK and EU agree to a second extension not contingent on May deal. (This option may not be accounted for depending on criteria for what constitutes an extension.)
4) Hybrid approach, which is my preference and a likely outcome. May Deal is not considered or fails to pass. An emergency EU summit in which a new extension date, with different or no caveats for UK qualifying for extension is proposed, approved by EU, and this date is presented to Parliament which agrees AND ALSO agrees internally as to a plan forward that bypasses the May deal. This may require revocation to avoid unintended hard Brexit aka crash out, but with an internal agreement that Article 50 be invoked again after one or more of the following: 
1) EU election is held and UK contingent is seated.
3) New UK snap election after 14 April.
2) New referendum. 
( Mathematically, there is a fair way to do this by splitting the question AND asking a separate, new multiple choice question for type of Brexit v remain. Using weighted scores and using the higher of the first referendum leave vote or the second in weighting, it is possible to both give Brexit and remain an opportunity to prevail, while also providing Brexiteers the opportunity to both confirm their leave vote without risk AND give direction to the Government and Parliament to proceed towards a Hard Brexit, May's deal (which the EU has agreed to accept) or start over by writing new, different Article 50 invocation law which includes indications from the People and Parliament to guide the Government's UK negotiators toward a deal that is more likely to pass Parliament. And it avoids Brexiteers having the first referendum stolen by asking only a question that pits multiple forms of Brexit against one simple remain choice, which would guarantee failure for Brexit.

On may 21st, the Premier May accepted the agreement proposed by the EU 27 for an extension of the article 50. The UK Parliament has to approve or not the above-citedagreement: if it passes, the new deadline would be on the 22nd of May, increasing the possibility of implementing a new deal;  if it fails the parliament has to choose between an extension till the 12 April or no extension, generating chaos about the siituation on the 29th of March. I think that the UK will take time to decide what to do, for sure until the 12 April and very likely also over the 22 of May. In both case, the UK would try to understand what to do, for example asking for further extension and negotiations, postponing that to very late 2019. They could also reconsider the option of a new referendum (we should remember there is a petition of more than 5 millions people to discourage Brexit), but again during this new extension period, and for sure not on the 29th of March, for the reasons I explained in my previous forecast.
From the EU point of view, I think they neither have advantages from a no deal and would prefer to let the UK fix its domestic policy and decide how to procede: they agreed for the two possible extensions (12 april and 22 May), and I think they could go further. Indeed, even if it would be complicated and triggering including the UK in the European elections, the EU would prefer this option rather than a no deal.

On March 21st, May accepted Bruxelles’ propositions on potential extension dates. If the UK deputies approve the agreement, an extension will be granted to May 22nd, but if the UK deputies reject the agreement once again, a shorter extension will be granted, to April 12th. In my opinion, Bruxelles’ move on extension perspectives confirms the previous forecast, on the EU very low interest in having a “no deal”. On that note, considering the UK deputies’ reject for the current agreement with the EU, it is most likely that the UK deputies reject the agreement once again very soon.  0% Neither of the above will occur and the UK will leave the EU 
In the face of Bruxelles’ decision this week, it is not possible that the 27 change their mind before next Friday. However, this scenario seems to remain widely open after April 12th, considering the French President’s latest declarations on a "no deal". 0% it will be revoked by the UK: More than one million of UK citizens have signed an online petition for revoking the Article 50. However, from a political/reputational perspective and besides Bruxelles' latest compromise, there is no chance that May will erase long weeks of negotiations with both the Parliament and the EU and finally decide to cancel the Brexit before or after March 29th. Moreover, the Brexit was central to May’s political projects/election and has declared that she was going to stick with the popular decision of 2016. In that sense, she does not mention this option publicly but declares instead that it’s time for decision in regard to the context of Brexit.
An extension until 12 April now looks almost certain.

Considering the fact that the notification of Article 50 by the UK has been granted an extension at the point in time when I am forecasting (the 23rd of March)  to the 12th of April, I will now answer the question considering the new extended deadline.
The EU granted the three weeks extension on the condition that the UK needs to pass her Brexit deal on a third attempt.  If the MPs approve May's deal, the EU will then extend the Brexit deadline further to the 22nd of May, thus giving the UK time to pass the required domestic legislation. The EU Parliament must also ratify the deal, but that’s expected to be mostly a formality. Because May was forced to ask for a delay in the deadline, there is a good chance that Brexit will be even further delayed.  The delay creates a precedent, which is the reason why I give it an optimistic 35% likelihood. In this case of events, the Prime Minister comes up with a new plan in 3 weeks' time to move past the political paralysis which is already causing exasperation among other European leaders. However, the Parliament rejected May's plan by 230 votes in January and by 150 votes the second time, which is a massive margin to make up. It is still looking very likely that the Parliament will defeat the proposal once again. I believe it is 15% more likely that the UK will leave without a deal on the 12th of April because an extension beyond this date is only possible if the UK agrees to hold European elections on the 23th of May. While the delay might seem like it impeded the immanence of a no-deal Brexit, I believe that in reality it made it even more likely — given the very slight prospect of a sustainable Brexit deal passing and the fact that May has said the UK will not take part in the vote. The Prime Minister is left with less and less space to breathe. Lastly, I believe there is a thin chance of 15% that the article is revoked, primarily because the Prime Minister — who does have the power to potentially cancel it — has confirmed her strong opposition. Still the chance in my forecast is justified by the petition to cancel Brexit which has reached 4 million signatures. However, the chance is slim considering House of Commons leader Andrea Leadsom dismissed the petition as not being on the same scale as the pro-Brexit vote in the 2016 referendum: 'Should it reach 17.4 million respondents then I am sure there will be a very clear case for taking action,' she told MPs. All in all, my forecast is that as of 23rd of March 2019, the UK is most likely to leave the EU on the 12th of April without a deal.

UPDATE 20.03.2019  Donald Tusk’s press conference addressing the Brexit affirms the used assumptions in the previous forecasts. He states that a short extension is possible and also feasible to agree on. As stated in previous forecasts, this seems to be more favourable to the EU than a long extension. He also stresses that, despite a Brexit “fatigue”, the EU should be welcoming any effort to avoid a hard-Brexit even if chances are low. The reason why the likelihoods remain unchanged lies in the stated requirements for this extension: no renegotiations about the current withdrawal agreement. However, as stated before, if minor changes would lead to a soft-Brexit then the EU will accept renegotiations in my humble opinion.  It is worth to mention that May’s government asked for a short extension of Article 50 rather than a long one as assumed in the previous forecast. This assumption is based on John Bercow’s block of a third vote if the deal isn’t changed sufficiently. It seems, that May and her government plan to circumvent this block by the Speaker. Furthermore, it shows that they plan to finally gain a majority for their deal in the British Parliament within the extension period rather than risking a hard-Brexit.  This dilemma, the need to change the agreement while the EU isn’t willing to renegotiate, poses an uncertainty regarding future developments.  Source:  -	BBC 2019: Tusk: Short Brexit extension ‘possible’ – BBC News: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iy-LQ73Omco

It is now impossible for the UK to leave EU by 29th March with a deal, because no further vote on the WA is scheduled and even if a vote was won by the Government their is now insufficient time to pass the required legislation by 29th March. The only way that the UK could now leave the EU on 29th would be via a crash out "no deal", which MPs will be allow. A50 could be revoked to avoid a crash out and revoking would happening if the European Council refuses an extension. 
However the UK has asked for a "short extension" until 30th June and Tusk has said he would recommend a "short extension" if the UK parliament voted for the WA (Withdrawal Agreement that May has already agreed with the EU). it might only be until 22nd May rather than the 30th June (i.e before the EU elections, rather than May's date of before the new EU parliament sits)
What Tusk did not say today was, what would happen if the UK parliament did not vote for the WA before 29th March. The reason for not saying now is probably that Mrs May has only asked for a "short extension" and the only reason was wanting it that she gave in her letter to Tusk, was to have another to get her WA passed by parliament. 
It is almost certain that if the UK parliament does not vote for the WA before the 29th March (and unless Mrs May can convince the Speaker that the WA is in some significant way different to the WA that parliament voted down last week, he will not allow Mrs May to even put it to parliament) Mrs May would need to do what she had previously said she was going to do, and sentdTusk another request to extend A50 for a period long enough to change the WA, and explain her plan for getting the WA changed (by a change of PM, a general election or referendum for example). Tusk did not say that he had ruled this option out.
In my opinion putting pressure on MP to vote for May's WA in order to get an A50 extension will have little effect because may Conservative and DUP MPs say they would be happy to crash out of the EU, so they (say) that crashing out on 29th Match is better than May's WA.

UPDATE 19.03.2019 The reassessment is based on the recent events caused by the Speaker of the House of Commons and its implications for the British government’s Brexit strategy.  John Bercow declared that he won’t allow a third vote on May’s deal if no major changes happened pursuant to a convention about parliamentary proceeding rules from 1604. His decision makes it less likely that May will go for a third vote in the next weeks according to Laura Knuessberg, BBC’s political editor. As a result, so Knuessberg, the British government won’t ask for a short-time extension in order to gain time for a soft-Brexit transition period (under the circumstance that the Parliament voted in favour for it, which seems unlikely anyway). It is worth to mention that these parliamentary proceeding rules could be changed or circumvented in some way. Despite that, it seems that the most reasonable request would be to ask for a longer extension period in order to gain more MPs for a new deal which is also acceptable for the EU. A process which definitely requires more time than 10 days.  The EU itself reaffirmed its stance that a delay will only be accepted if there is a feasible plan for a soft-Brexit without fundamental re-negotiations. However, statements like these could be of tactical nature to improve the EU’s position in possible upcoming negotiations. In my opinion, the EU and its member states are likely to accept renegotiations if fundamental EU laws are adhered to and if this new deal would lead to a soft-Brexit in the end.  Nonetheless, I adjust the likelihood from 9% to 20% in favour for a hard-Brexit due to these new developments. As stated before (in UPDATE 15.03.19): a longer extension period (the most reasonable request by May’s government) would result in the participation of the UK in EU elections which isn’t in favour of the EU and its member states, thus, increasing the likelihood that the EU/one of its members will decline/vote against it.  Sources:  BBC 2019: Brexit. Update Tuesday 19 March 2019 :
New events are to be specified for the update of this forecast.
Indeed,
- The new (second) vote on the Brexit agreement was rejected by a large majority on 12 March.
- The Speaker of the Parliament, John Bercow, said there will be no new vote on the Brexit agreement if the British government does not change the text (arguing an old parliamentary convention not used since 1912 ). But the European Union has repeatedly stated that the agreement will not be renegotiated. So we arrive at a "constitutional chaos" according to the Telegraph and The Guardian, which reinforces the uncertainty in the event.
- Meeting at the European Summit on the 21st and 22nd of March where Theresa May will very probably ask for an extension of the deadline. However, the EU has warned that any extension must be duly justified and accepted unanimously by the 27. According to AFP, for France, an extension of the negotiations is "neither obvious nor automatic". Europeans want a "credible initiative" to avoid a divorce without agreement. Nathalie Loiseau, French Minister for European Affairs, said that "if no decision is made, the date of March 29 will fall, and it will be a non-agreement". Alternative to a vote bypassing Bercow and therefore Brexit March 29 with an agreement (May announced to redo the agreement in Parliament by March 20):
-According to Nikki Da Costa, a former legal adviser to the Prime Minister, Theresa May could use a "motion" to prove that there is a majority in the House of Commons for another meaningful vote despite Bercow's statements.
-The possibility of allowing MPs to decide whether or not to ignore the 400-year-old convention invoked by John Bercow, and whether they vote in that direction to submit the withdrawal agreement a third time next week. So there is a lot of uncertainties about this unprecedented event, and we can not say for sure what will happen in the next few days. Even if the extension of the deadline seems the most likely (I would say 60% of likelihood), it is very far from being impossible to have some kind of European punishment against the UK with the advent of a No-Deal (with for example France which refuses to examine the extension and thus the unanimity of the 27 is not reached), even if it seems very damageable and little in the interest in Europe (approximately 15%). We should also note the possibility of Theresa May's unpredictable turn-around, which will unexpectedly result in a re-vote and thus validate the revised Brexit agreement by the Parliament, thus carrying out Brexit on March 29 without extension (20%).
Whatever happens, the decision can be taken up to an hour before the official date of Brexit, which reinforces its uncertain character.

Because of that and the interest of the European Union to avoid a hard Brexit, the forecast at hand adapts its prediction towards a highly likely Extension of the negotiations - as of 85%. A 10% likelihood of a no deal Brexit is estimated to be left due to the fact that all member states have to agree upon the extension. A 5% chance that Brexit got stopped by the UK itself is estimated to be left due to the high degree of uncertainty around the issue, which is why self-critically no scenario should be excluded at this point of time.

The whole Brexit process is now becoming a farce or a constitutional crisis. You can choose which.
The Speaker has just ruled that under a 400 year old rule Mrs May is not allowed to bring her EU Withdrawal Agreement motion back for a 3rd try to pass it unless it is substantially different to the one voted down last week.   He has ruled that there were changes between the try in January and the try last week.
The Solicitor General has said that Parliament may need to be prorogued to allow the motion to be reintroduced. (You can vote on the same thing in different sessions.)
Clearly these action are against the spirit of the rules parliament, and show what a mess its in if these sorts of measures are being taken. Normal convention is that if a PM loses an important vote they resign. Its unprecedented for a PM to lose a vote by as much as Mrs May has done not to resign. Its obviously unprecedented for  a PM to lose what is in effect two votes for the same thing to not resign. As far as I know no PM has ever tried to tried get around the rules by proroguing parliament (since 1948). This sort of behavour is not supposed to happen in the UK parliament. 
So whatever the outcome of this particular vote Mrs May will go down in history as the person who wrecked the traditional way of parliamentary behavior.
The question is will any of this work for Mrs May? The current thinking is that even if May gets her WA motion voted on again, and even if the DUP suddenly  decides that Mrs May deal is just what they always wanted and vote for it (any extra money for NI would, I am sure, not influence them at all) and some of ERG (hard Brexiteers) who it now seems don't really have any of their own principals, they will just follow what ever the DUP does, also vote for May's deal,  Mrs May would probable still not get her deal through. Why would it get voted through? Brexiteers and Remainers are all agreed its a very bad deal, and Mrs May herself said "no deal is better than a bad deal", and hers is certainly a bad deal. 
Of course May could now threaten to just prorogue parliament until April so that it cannot change the A50 leaving date. That would set the constitution on fire!   
Its still almost 100% certain that A50 will be extended.

With the UK parliamentary vote of 413 against 202 for the Brexit extension [1], it is almost certain that there will be an extension.  (There is no way that EU will deny this extension request lest it would be blamed for the chaos with a quick no-deal Brexit).  What is going to happen after 29 March?  While it is not part of this challenge question, but it is most interesting. We can get insights of what is going to happen by examining the various parliamentary votes.  The May Brexit deal was defeated twice in the UK Parliament by large margins (432 versus 202 for the original deal, and 391 versus 242 for the modified deal).  These votes mean that May's Brexit deal does not have majority support in the Parliament.  It does not mean that Brexit does not have support. The vote on no-deal Brexit is most revealing.  No-deal Brexit was rejected by only 4 votes (312 versus 308) with 30 MPs not voted.  It could have past easily.  Although this particular vote does not have much legal standing, it reveals clearly that the pro-Brexit sentiment in the parliament is much stronger than what was shown in the May Brexit deal votes.  I am surprised that there are 308 MPs willing to go for Brexit with no deal. The path to Brexit for these 308 is narrow.  A long extension could possibly lead to a second referendum which could result in a soft Brexit or no Brexit at all.  EU has already said a short extension is not useful unless UK can agree to a deal.  It looks like the modified May Brexit deal is "hardest" Brexit deal that UK can get.  So the hard Brexiteers (the 308 that voted for no-deal Brexit, and possibly more in the 30 that did not vote)  have to make a choice soon: a not-so-desirable Brexit or no Brexit.  Since they are willing to risk a no-deal Brexit, it is likely that they will vote for May's deal between now and 29 March.  If that is the case, then Brexit will happen after the short extension.  This would save UK (and the world) from further drama and economic risks. Comments? [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-47576813

UPDATE 15.03.2019 The likelihoods of the above forecast remain almost the same after the British Parliament has overwhelmingly voted in favour for a delay of Brexit beyond the 29th of March. (The minor changes regarding option 1 and 3 are explained in the last paragraph). The uncertainty regarding this forecast is based on the future decision of the European Council, respectively the stances of the remaining EU member states, if the EU should accept or decline the extension request. The final decision to remain with the initially set likelihood for the second option is rooted in the comparison of arguments for and against an extension of Brexit out of a European perspective:  AGAINST: 
a) EU states are unwilling to agree on an extension which results in negotiations of a completely new deal
b) Disbelief in British government managing to pass a withdrawal agreement which makes an extension useless for the EU 
c) A long extension period would mean that the UK would have to participate in the EU election in May. Fear of ‘revenge votes’ from British citizens limits willingness to grant an extension  FOR: 
a) Despite the official statement that the EU doesn’t intent to re-negotiate the last deal it could still be possible that EU officials agree on a new deal with minor changes if this one is likely to pass the British Parliament. The recent decisions in the UK might send a signal to the EU that there is a realistic chance for a soft-Brexit 
b) Short time extension would allow a smoother transition with more laws implemented by UK/EU to mitigate social/political/economic risks 
c) A longer extension period would enable major political changes such as withdrawal from Brexit or a general election within UK. 
The result of this comparison is that the EU should be definitely in favour for a short-term extension as the efforts/costs to do so are fairly limited while the possible outcomes would mitigate social/political/economic damages to the EU. A long-term extension is less likely due to its implications on EU’s election in May. The rest chance for a denied extension is mainly based on the possibility of a non-ambiguous decision within the EU Council which derives from a current atmosphere of mistrust. It is possible that some actors might use their voting power to deliberately cause a hard-Brexit. Nonetheless, the decision regarding the Brexit have been coherent in the last two years.  The change of likelihood regarding the first and last option is based on the short time period left up to the 29th of March. It is more likely that a hard-Brexit occurs rather than a withdrawal of the Brexit for three reasons: 
1)	It seems unrealistic that May would dare to revoke the Article 50 in the case of a lost voting on her third attempt to pass a deal. She would likely lose the trust and support of MPs in this scenario which limits her capabilities to pursue to revoke Article 50. Aditionally, she is personally against it
2) The remain faction isn't able to gather enough MPs to force a withdrawal (see last forecast) 
3)	The hard-Brexit is still the legally binding result in the case of a failed attempt to pass May’s deal or a failed extension despite the decision of the British Parliament at the 13th of March (see last forecast) Source:

The instability posed from the internal quarrels in the Parliament give a basis for a growing destabilizing ambiguity over the set up date in March. This gives twofold opportunity for the politicians in power to promote the opinion of revoking Article 50, which would mean stopping Brexit in full. According to the European Court of Justice the decision to revoke Article 50  must be “unequivocal and unconditional”, contrary to its imposition. It seems to me that the chances to be revoked before 30th March, although possible, are relatively low. First, because it is 15th March already and in the Parliament talks about extension of the transition has already started following uncertain trade deal between UK and EU. The decision to revoke Article 50 needs to be unambiguious, which is not possible in the unearthed political situation in the UK, therefore in my view, I see a very high possibility and likelihood of prolonging the process of leaving for the UK due to the unsettled trade deal and the rest of business relations between the UK and EU. While I cannot claim certainty over what will occur in the future two weeks, it seems very unlikely for the last answer- neither a decisions to revoke, nor an extension, because this would leave the UK in a regulatory misbehavior in relation to the EU and it will further weaken its political power. In conclusion, timing is the most important part of the question. UK can unilaterally revoke article 50 before 29th March 2019 when its withdrawal agreement will enter into force. But the UK can also revoke it after that date only if the European Council agrees to extend the transition period of Article 50 beyond 29th March 2019. Having said that, according to news from 14th March 2019, European Council is quite content with the deal drafted, which the UK rejects, and the former is ready for Britain to leave the EU, but it is about the UK maybe being unable as of not ready to leave in two weeks. Moreover, the European elections are coming in May 2019, so if Theresa May and the British Parliament manage to make a diplomatic move towards the EU Council for an extension, this extension would be for no more than a month and a half, as the EU Council would prevent the UK having any power in the elections and drawing more comfortable deal. A decision of revoking would however give an upper hand for the UK to prepare in better terms - meaning if they manage to create a more beneficial gathering of diplomatic ties in the EU following the elections and since no other country has so far left EU or revoked Article 50, this leaves a creativity vacuum for the UK to normatively exploit.

Received from https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-47564793 Theresa May will make a third attempt to get her EU withdrawal deal through Parliament in the next week. She told MPs that if her deal fails again to get their backing, a lengthy delay to Brexit may be needed. The prime minister's warning comes ahead of a Commons vote later on whether to ask the EU for permission to delay Brexit beyond 29 March. MPs voted on Wednesday evening to reject a no-deal Brexit under any circumstances. No date has yet been set for the third so-called "meaningful vote". But BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg said that even if the UK is given until the end of June to pass the legislation required to leave the EU, the government will try to do that earlier, if Mrs May's deal is passed next week. Alternatively, there could be a much longer delay, requiring the UK to take part in elections for the European Parliament in May, the prime minister has said, in the event her deal is not approved. The updated motion, to reject a no-deal Brexit under any circumstances, was passed by 321 to 278, a majority of 43. However, Wednesday's no-deal vote is not binding - under current law the UK could still leave without a deal on 29 March, unless an extension is agreed with the EU.
Speaking after the result of the vote was read out, Mrs May said: "The options before us are the same as they always have been. "The legal default in EU and UK law is that the UK will leave without a deal unless something else is agreed. The onus is now on every one of us in this House to find out what that is." It will be revoked by the UK - 
The low likelihood for this outcome is based on the reluctance of the major political actors towards it. Theresa May and the majority of the Conservative Party still support the Brexit despite disagreements if it should be a soft or hard one. The Labour Party is unlikely to support a remain policy either. Its political leader, Jeremy Corbyn, declared that his target is to trigger new general elections. He will only support the remain camp under the circumstance of failing to trigger new elections. It is worth to note, that Corbyn prefers the UK to leave the EU due to his own political goals of nationalizing parts of the British economy. The group of MPs who are in favour of remaining in the EU aren’t likely to gather enough support to stop the Brexit within the remaining time.  It will be extended by the UK and the European Council -  
So far, an extension seems to be the most likely outcome at the 14th of March, because all key political actors would benefit from it. Theresa May would be able to re-negotiate with the European Union to achieve concessions regarding issues which steered controversy within her party and coalition in order to pass a withdrawal agreement (e.g.: through a new solution to replace the backstop clause, hence, regaining popularity within the DUP). Nonetheless, there is still a possibility that Conservative MPs will vote against May’s agreements as happened at the 15th of January and 12th of March, as well as, that Labour MPs will vote against an extension as happened at the 30th of January. The European Union might agree to changes if a new deal is likely to pass the British Parliament as several EU and government officials from different EU-countries stated their preference for a soft-Brexit rooted in concerns regarding the likely economic slump in case of a hard-Brexit. As Labour doesn’t support May’s former deal or a hard-Brexit, they are likely to vote in favour for an extension as this would enable Labour to shift decision-making on Brexit from the government to the parliament or to take over the government due to new general elections.  Neither of the above will occur and the UK will leave – 
The British Parliament voted against a “no-deal-Brexit” scenario, thus, decreasing the likelihood of such an outcome. Nonetheless, there is still a chance that such a scenario could occur. As Theresa May stated, this result isn’t legally binding. As long as the Parliament doesn’t vote in favour for a particular agreement with the EU, or if the British Parliament and/or the European Union decline an extension, a no-deal-Brexit still remains the default protocol. Supporters of a “no-deal-Brexit” would vote against an extension in order to force the UK into this scenario, but recent votes demonstrated that the hard-Brexit faction is shrinking indeed.  To summarize the findings above: extending the notification of Article 50 beyond the 29th of March would please most MPs and represent the least decisive decision to go for as it doesn't determine if the UK will leave the EU with a hard-Brexit or won't leave at all. The forecast at hand attests a British withdrawal from the Brexit a 0% chance due to several reasons. First, neither the the conservatives nor Labour support revoking attempts (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/comment/brexit-tories-labout-eu-uk-single-market-customs-union-jeremy-corbyn-theresa-may-a8386526.html). This holds true even after Corbyn and thus Labour’s latest repositioning in favor of a second referendum (https://www.politico.eu/article/jeremy-corbyn-brexit-labour-backs-second-brexit-vote-to-stop-theresa-may-deal/). The dominance of Brexit supporters, both radical and moderate in the conservative party will prevent any withdrawal attempts on the part of the Conservatives. The same applies to May’s conservative government. Her Brexit course and categorical denial to revoke the Brexit so far, as well as the fact that her political survival depends on the further implementation of the Brexit speaks for itself. Even if Labour could assert itself with its idea of a second referendum, polls haven’t changed since Brexit (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-45098550). Even if a majority would vote in favor of remaining in the EU, the win would be most likely narrow and the referendum’s legitimacy would be highly contested. Thus, the obstacles to Britain's remaining in the European Union are so high that this scenario can be ruled out. This week (CW 9), the events have overturned. May had to give up her resistance to the postponement of the exit date, which she had so far categorically ruled out. Due to pressure from more pro-EU members of her party and government, as well as the fact that there is only little time left (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-47352446), May presented a three steps plan: On the 12th of march the parliament will be asked to vote on her modified Brexit deal with the EU, in case of a rejection, the parliamentarians will vote on an exit without deal on the following day. If they oppose that idea, too, the parliament will get the chance to vote on an extension of the negotiations (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/feb/26/mps-offered-vote-on-no-deal-brexit-and-possible-delay). However, this did not increase the likelihood of the extension to realize - a 30% likelihood is assumed at the forecast at hand.The likelihood have been moderate since some time now with a huge majority in the British parliament, rejecting the idea of a chaotic Brexit (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/jan/20/mps-to-ambush-may-with-amendments-to-stop-no-deal-brexit) and positive signals from Brussels and its member states (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/jan/16/germany-and-france-signal-willingness-to-delay-brexit), as well as the tight time plane. However, as described in Answer 3, May’s three step plan drastically increased the possibility of a majority in the parliament in favor of a modified deal.  Imposant for this alternative is that it actually consists out of two: the UK will leave the EU with May’s modified deal or without a deal at all. With May’s announcement of her three steps plan today, the likelihood of the latter reduced drastically, while the other options, a postponed exit, as well as the British parliament accepting May’s modified deal, got more likely to realize. The forecast at hand estimates that there is only a 10% likelihood left, that the UK leaves the EU without deal. The Britisch parliament accepting the deal however, got paradoxically more likely today - the paper at hand estimates now a likelihood of 60% - when May announced the option of an extension of the negotiations. Until now, the Brexit advocates within the conservatives had called for an "opening" of the withdrawal agreement negotiated with Brussels to include changes to the backstop solution for Northern Ireland. Their leader Rees-Mogg said in several interviews on Wednesday that he could also be satisfied with an additional protocol („Appendix") (https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/tory-brexiteers-soften-their-position-dlwcztcqp).The change of course reflects the growing concern of the Brexit advocates that a renewed rejection of the deal could lead to a postponement of the withdrawal date. With a view to the exit-critical majority in the lower house of parliament, they fear that the parliament could vote in favour of a "softer" Brexit or even a second referendum in the extension phase. This first step towards May, also reflects the volatileness of British positions towards the Brexit. With May changing her mind on the extension, the hardliners towards and opening and Labour towards a second referendum, a moving on the British side can get observed. The rising willingness to compromise is most likely to increase further over the next weeks due to approaching exit date. Even though the EU has been very firm on their stances so far, so far they only have excluded an re-opening of the agreement. Thus, finding a compromise, e.g. in the Appendix could be an option, in particular because the EU cannot be interested in a chaotic Brexit either. --> 10%+60%=70%

It will be revoked: Theresa May has on numerous occasions rejected the idea of revoking the Article 50 notification and thereby terminating Brexit. While Labour has officially announced their support for a second referendum (https://edition.cnn.com/2019/02/26/uk/may-brexit-article-50-announcement-gbr-intl/index.html), and the ‘Remain Movement’ continues to loudly campaign for a turnaround, May is unlikely to go down this route. Speaking directly on the issue, May argued that it would leave the country in a no better position than where it is now at (‘Orientering’, dr.dk, 26.2.19, 0:14). It echoes previous statements made by the prime minister, wherein she has insisted that the decision of the British people must be respected.  It will be extended by the UK and the European Council: In her address to Parliament on February 26th, May stated that should her exit deal fail to be ratified in the March 12th vote, parliament will be asked to vote,  firstly on whether or not to leave the EU without a deal, and potentially then, on a push-back of the date for the Article 50 notification. Several PMs have stepped forward in support of extension in a bid to avoid a no-deal scenario, and it is expected that the extension will be supported by both Labour and Conservative members (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/feb/26/mays-deal-no-deal-or-brexit-delay-how-will-mps-vote). However, where official EU statements have indicated an openness to talks of an extension of article 50, both France and Spain have recently sharpened their rhetoric, underlining than an extension will not be supported without conditions (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/feb/27/spanish-pm-warns-may-brexit-delay-with-no-plan-not-reasonable-or-desirable). However, despite roars from these large EU states, the EU will likely come to an agreement to allow the extension. The EU is better served with a controlled Brexit and the appearance of a ‘united front’ is without a doubt most desirable in the face of a British departure.  Neither of the above will occur and the UK will leave EU: It could be that May lets ‘time work for her’, and that the fear of a no-deal Brexit will inspire some to vote in favor of her deal (https://www.weekendavisen.dk/2019-6/samfund/med-uret-som-medspiller). Similarly, the fear of a delayed Brexit could inspire some hardcore Brexiters to also vote in favor of her deal – simply to not extend the departure from the EU any further. Hence, May's deal could pass in the vote on March 12th, especially if a change to the back-stop issues is managed. But, his is not a likely feat.  However, it also is a possibility that May and the parliament fail to the agree on an exit deal for the UK and a no-deal Brexit will be realized. However, it seems that a majority is against this outcome, as the political and economic consequences seem overwhelming.

When faced with a difficult situation, people tend to procrastinate. Kicking the can down the road is the best solution right now for almost all parties: Brexit supporters against Theresa May's proposal, Brexit opponents, and the EU. For Brexit opponents and the EU, the best outcome is for there to be no Brexit. But if that happens, it is very unlikely to happen before March 30. The most likely way that could happen is for it to be decided in a second referendum, but holding a referendum requires a minimum of 21 weeks. The second way to revoke Article 50 is for parliament to do so without a second referendum. But that is extremely unlikely, since that would surely spark an angry response from the pro-Brexit camp, and divide the anti-Brexit camp. Support for Brexit has been slowly dipping in the polls, but still remains strong both on the streets and in parliament. For Brexit supporters who are against May's proposal, a delay would also, at least from their perspective, appear to give them time to pursue a different plan. They, too, are probably counting on a second referendum to approve their amendments. There is a minority who still want a hard Brexit; however, even among this group, most are hoping for a backstop solution to Northern Ireland, something that the EU would have no reason to honour after a hard Brexit. As for a reinstatement of a hard border in Ireland, there is as yet no noticeable support for that. Finally, while there are Conservatives who back May's plan, they are more resigned to it than enthusiastic about it. Some, including May, were against Brexit to begin with. If the EU grants an extension, they have little reason to not take it. In sum, I would be extremely surprised if Brexit is canceled before March 30, with or without a referendum. I would be quite surprised if Brexit happens before March 30, either with a hard Brexit or with the UK parliament deciding to back May's current deal. The most likely outcome is procrastination, with many hoping to ultimately wake up from this nightmare unscathed.

The premier May is trying to build an agreement to satisfy both the various tendencies internal to her party and the EU requests, with the result of not satisfying almost anyone. So far, the proposal of agreement has not been accepted by the English Parliament (January 2019) and the actual one seems to be still “not good enough". 
One of the key issues is that is not possible to suspend abruptly the European regulation, therefore the UK will have to honour its commitment with the EU (and vice versa) until 2030, keeping ploughing money to EU. 
Moreover, there is the problem of the free movements of goods and people. In order to don’t create damages to the economy and to the multinational enterprises, the proposal is to keep the UK in the European Economic Area (EEA), which include EU members and not-members but avoid them to stipulate economic agreement with States outside the European framework.
In the end, there is the Ireland issue, where the Republic of Ireland (RI) risk to remain physically isolated from Europe and, above all, from Northern Ireland (NI). In fact, so far, the NI and RI have been divided but thanks to the Good Friday Agreement (1998) and to the fact of being both part of the EU, the tensions between the two have been defused amd the free movement of goods and people guaranteed. If UK and EU won’t find and agreement concerning this issue, in order to guarantee the safety of NI and RI, the UK will have to remain in the EEA. 
In my opinion, it will be difficult to find an agreement better than this one because the entire issue is very complex, but currently the UK is not satisfied by it and there are still some unresolved issues. Even the President of the European Council, D. Tusk, has recently expressed his preference in making an extension to the Article 50. 
In conclusion, even if the situation is complex, between the two the EU is the one who has the upper hand: I think that in this moment it is more powerful than UK, can implement easier its strategy and impose its rules, pushing the UK to accept the current agreement or asking for an extension of the Article 50. 40% No deal

Therefore, leaving has 44% as an outside view. However, there has been a substantial public commitment to this outcome, possibly raising the stakes for May & co. This is also now the default option -- we leave if parliament remains tied up with in-fighting. We also have the option of taking the deal offered to us. Both party leader's mixed opinions on staying in the EU probably can only swing 2.5% total, but they stand together(ish) on getting us out of the EU. We therefore have 39% likelihood to split between the other two options. I argue that an extension is more palatable to parliament than revocation. Revocation would be disregarding a referendum -- even if it was non-binding.   Maybe as much as 2.5x more palatable, giving a 28/11 split on extension/revocation.

REVOKE: 1%. Since the European Court of Justice ruled that UK can unilaterally choose to remain in the EU, as a final outcome, I would have given a 15% chance of the UK revoking the deal. However, since the question is focused on what might happen from now to March 30, I see the revoke option as very unlikely. Unless extraordinary changes or a black swan in the English political environment happened (the reason why I maintained a 1% possibility), considering the course of events there is no time to activate such option. In fact, the UK in order to not undermine the stability of its common low creating a dangerous precedent could opt for revoking only after a new referendum (which, as a matter of fact, the “remain” would be likely to win). However, since with the conservative party is in power this will never happen (as Theresa May has reiterated more than once). This scenario would be possible (not certain) only after new elections, the labor party in power and with their willingness to call for a new Referendum. Hence, even though such a complex scenario might unfold in the coming months, there wouldn’t be enough time to ask directly to revoke Article 50, the UK would have to ask for an extension and, only after that, start an internal discussion which might bring to a legitimization of a new referendum.  NO-DEAL: 29%. As the Tory minister Tobias Ellwood recently stated, "There are many ministers, me being one of them, that need to see 'no deal' removed from the table,". Furthermore, May sent a letter to each member of the parliament highlighting the need to find a solution to this impasse and also warning that “the history will judge us”. Therefore, it is clear that (almost) nobody wants a hard Brexit (no deal) as an outcome. The same is true for the counterpart: the European Union. The interests at stake are too high for both sides.  As recently warned by the Bank of England, the UK economy could shrink by 8% in the immediate aftermath if there was no transition period. A dramatic scenario that, if true, could threaten directly the resilience and stability of all the major English institutions. On the other side, Europe wouldn’t be able to guarantee the rights of millions of European citizens on British soil (besides all the economic consequence which UK would also face). However, a no-deal outcome cannot be completely downplayed since many other factors could play a role. Matters of proud and credibility could push aside the objectively dramatic drawbacks of a no deal option. The Labour party might bid on nationalism as a tool to gain new voters and then call for new elections. On the other side, also the European Union may refuse an extension of article 50 in order to give a strong message to the UK and all the European countries about the consequences of leaving the EU. However, considering the consequences of a no deal, I consider this evidence possible but unlikely.  EXTENDED: 70%. For the reason expressed above, I consider an extension of article 50 before March 31 as the most likely scenario. As said, a no-deal would lead to consequences that are above the tolerance level for both parts. Furthermore, the UK's main opposition party, the Labours, wants to force a general election and, after winning it, go back to Brussels to negotiate its version of Brexit. On the other side, the EU might agree to extend Article 50 if its leaders thought it would help smooth the process or if there was a chance the UK could end up staying in, possibly through another referendum. Finally, even in the case of a no deal, some government ministers have already publically talked about asking the EU for an extension of a few weeks to get all the necessary legislation through Parliament. It will be revoked: 
This is highly unlikely. May is politically bound to see through the deal: revoking article 50 would be seen as a betrayal to pro-Brexit voters. May has expressed no intention to do so (Carrell, Guardian: 10 Dec).  It will be extended by the UK and EU: 
At such a late stage in the transition period and with no agreement having yet been reached, an extension of the notification is most likely. For the UK, a no-deal would create a highly uncertain, and potentially calamitous, economic and political climate. It is in their best interest to lodge a request for extension.  For the extension to occur the European Council must agree unanimously. While this gives states veto power, the EU will likely put forward a united front for the sake of its strategic interests. Since there is no law governing the length of a possible extension, the EU is in a position to make that grant on its own terms.

Neither occurs, UK leaves EU: 
For the reasons articulated above, this is unlikely — though a greater possibility than article 50 being revoked. Given May’s political commitment, it is unlikely a no-deal Brexit will occur on British terms. However, with EU elections approaching, there is some chance one or more EU member states — worrying about its effects — may opt to veto a request for extension.

What are May's options right now?
1) modify the deal with the EU to change the Irish backstop arrangements (3% probability)
2) modify the political declaration and hope to get the deal through the Commons that way (20%)
3) delay progress, threaten with no deal (67% as this is what seems to be happening)
4) make concessions to Labour to become independent of Tories and DUP to get a deal through the Commons (10%) For each of these scenarios, I have another layer in the decision tree about whether or not the deal or amended deal will pass through the Commons.
1) in the unlikely event that the EU will move on the backstop, I think the amended deal is highly likely (90%) to pass
2) in case the declaration is the only thing that sees some modification, I see a 40% probability of the amended deal to pass
3) in case the threat of no deal and time pressure are used to force the deal through the Commons, I also give it a 40% chance of passing
4) in case of concessions to Labour, which is also quite an unlikely scenario from what we know has been said publicly would however see a high probability (80%) of the amended deal passing. That being said, in this scenario there would also be the possibility that the more substantial renegotiations require more time and an extension could be requested. Given a deal in whatever shape or form did not pass Parliament, the next decision is whether the UK will request an extension or leave without a deal, and given the UK requests an extension whether the EU agrees to extend. As of the 28 January amendment votes, it is now less likely that the Article 50 deadline will be extended. The passage of the Brady amendment to replace the backstop to prevent a "hard border" in Ireland with vague "alternative arrangements" conflicts with EU statements that the backstop is non-negotiable. 
The deadline cannot be extended unilaterally. The EU must agree and they must be given time to debate and vote.
The rejection of the Spelman amendment requiring a vote whether or not to extend the deadline if May's "plan B" by 28 February makes extension less likely. Not having a date certain increases the likelihood of more postponements. More postponements increases the likelihood   'running out the clock' and an "accidental", "No Deal Brexit" — a prospect not entirely unwelcome in some quarters.

Yesterday's votes in the UK parliament changes my "reasons" slightly. 
It needs to be noted that the chance for parliament to express its views had appeared to be a one day only offer, but before the votes Mrs May promised that there will another chance in two weeks (13th or 14th Feb) this (presumably) prevented a number (20?) of government ministers who are strongly against a No Deal and who want a soft Brexit (the UK staying in a Customs Union/Single Market), and had threatened to resign from the government, from voting against the government.   Only two things were passed. 
One made it a bit clearer that parliament is against a "No Deal" Brexit. The size of majority for this is a bit misleading because of all the ministers who don't want No Deal could not vote for it this time,  If a similar vote comes back in two weeks it would be likely to get a lot more support.
The other thing that was passed instructed May to go back to the EU and negotiate for "some other arrangement" to replace the Irish Backstop. The EU has said it will not renegotiate, the UK parliament says it will not pass May's Deal unless it does. If  both sides refuse to move the default was supposed to  be that the UK would leave on 29th March with No Deal, but if parliament has ruled that out where does that get us? I am not claiming I have the answers, but here are some thoughts. If the EU does agree to renegotiate then surely under the EU mantra "nothing is agreed until everything is agreed" then the current May Deal would cease to exist. So it would not just be a case of changing a word or two, it would be a case of opening up everything that had been agreed so far and staring again. As it has taken two and half years to get the May's Deal that has been rejected, it seems unlikely that a totally new deal would be negotiated and agreed by all parties in the EU, ready for Mrs May to present to the UK parliament to be voted on the 14th Feb (which is the timetable May has put forward.)  It could be argued that parliament is only asking for the Irish Backstop to be changed, so only a few words need changing. I don't think this is true. The backstop is needed to satisfy the Red Lines set by the UK (and EU). If I were the EU I would only offer to reopen negotiations to look for "alternative arrangements" in return for Mrs May removing her Red Lines. With no Red Lines a completely different Withdrawal Agreement becomes possible. But (obviously) a totally new WA would take a lot longer than two weeks to agree, in fact it would take longer than from now to the 29th March, so A50 would need to be extended.    How likely is it that the EU would agree to reopen just the Irish Backstop agreement? They have said "no", so would they change their mind? I think politically it would be very difficult, as the EU would need to be very careful how backing down would appear to EU voters. If the EU was perceived as throwing Ireland under the bus in order to avoid the inconvenience of a No Deal Brexit, to the economies of the bigger EU countries that trade a lot with the UK (e.g. Germany, France, Spain, Netherlands) it would send the message to the (economically) smaller EU countries that if push came to shove the rich, big EU countries would value their economic wellbeing over EU solidarity. Even if it was explained that Ireland was the country at the greatest risk from a No Deal Brexit, it would look like the EU was giving up the Irish Backstop to protect the big countries not to help Ireland. So I can't see the EU doing it, unless the UK dropped its Red Lines. If we assume I am completely wrong and the EU changes the Irish Backstop and Mrs May brings a new agreement back to parliament on (or around) the 13th Feb it is not over. The hardline ERG section of the Conservative Party have not said they will give unconditional support to any new deal. All they have said is that they will support May going back to the EU and negotiating "an alternative", so maybe they will not like the "alternative" or maybe they will find fault with some other aspect of what comes back.  But for the sake of argument lets assume a WA does get through parliament around the 14th Feb. Almost everyone who knows anything about getting the necessary legislation through parliament is now saying that there is not time to get it done between 14th Feb and 29th March. So my conclusion is that A50 will have to be extended, the only questions are; for how long? And for what reason? It is possible, but very improbable, unless the government gets even more screwed up, that by playing chicken the UK could leave it too late to get the EU to agree extending A50 and the only way to prevent Brexit without the legislation being in place would be to Revoke A50.  My guess is that Corbyn will now try to avoid the opposition being seen to  be the ones asking parliament to extend A50 (and so be blamed for delaying Brexit) and try and make May be the one who has asked to extend A50. The UK has thrown itself at the mercy of Brussels over Brexit McGee (2019) January 29, states that: London (CNN)After months of Brexit hot air, the UK's lawmakers have finally given us some idea of what they want. May's so-called plan B was approved by a majority of members of parliament, with some amendments. And it's these amendments which have put flesh on the bones of that plan.
In short, Parliament has told us that it favors sending May back to Brussels to seek concessions on the Northern Ireland backstop. That's the part of the Withdrawal Agreement which aims to prevent the return of border infrastructure between the Republic of Ireland, which will remain in the EU, and Northern Ireland, which will leave with the UK. This has been the single most contentious issue in the ranks of Theresa May's Conservative Party.
In theory, Parliament also ruled out a no-deal Brexit. But it failed to pass any amendment that would have achieved that aim, such as commanding the government to request an extension to the March 29 Brexit deadline, in the event it couldn't pass a deal by the end of February. After two years of this nonsense, it's nothing short of remarkable that the people elected to represent the citizens of the UK still think that this is in their gift (Para. 1-3).
But there's a snag.
The EU has been consistent in saying that the Withdrawal Agreement is done, locked down, not up for renegotiation. It appears not to matter how many times EU officials, diplomatic sources or even May herself tells her rebels this, they seem to think someone is lying. But without the Withdrawal Agreement being reopened, the backstop cannot be changed (Para. 4).
And if the government eventually decides it wants an extension to the Brexit deadline, that must be agreed by the European Council -- the body which comprises the leaders of each member state. It would need to be approved unanimously, meaning any country can veto and, as I'm sure you can see, 28 is a big number.
Unless the UK is willing to concede that May's deal is dead, the EU is unlikely to give the UK more time to continue howling at the moon. As one European diplomatic source recently told me, the EU is loathe to redraft something which has taken 28 nations two years to negotiate in the hope of tweaking it with weeks to go (Para. 4-6). The threat also works for those mortified at the prospect of crashing out without a deal. The Article 50 process -- the official EU exit route -- is nearly over. Without a revocation of Article 50 -- the request of which is in the UK's gift, but is also a total headache -- the default is that the UK leaves the EU on March 29, with or without a deal. Again, back me, or burn the house down (Para. 12). McGee, L. (2019). The UK has thrown itself at the mercy of Brussels over Brexit. CNN. World. UK. 2102 GMT (0502 HKT) January 29, 2019. Britain’s House of Commons will vote on various Brexit measures today. Theresa May, the prime minister, still hopes to persuade MPs to back an amended version of the Brexit deal they rejected overwhelmingly two weeks ago. Some proposed amendments would constrain her government. One tries to stop Britain leaving the European Union without any deal on March 29th by requiring the government, if it has not passed a Brexit deal by February 26th, to ask the EU to extend the deadline. Others still ask Mrs May to renegotiate the Irish “backstop” to avert a hard border in Ireland, or even to scrap it by keeping the United Kingdom in a customs union with the EU. Yet the EU has said it cannot accept legal changes to the backstop. And extending the March 29th deadline requires all 28 EU members’ consent. Once again, what passes muster in Westminster could fail in Brussels, and vice versa.

Prime Minister Theresa May is backing a plan to ditch the most contentious part of her Brexit deal as she searches for a compromise all sides can support. In a meeting today, May effectively abandoned the agreement she's spent the past 18 months negotiating with the EU and threw the weight of her government behind a move to re-write the deal. She urged hundreds of Conservative politicians to support the proposal, which would strip out the so-called backstop plan for the Irish border, wrecking a compromise she's agreed to with the EU in the hope of securing one with her own party. I am looking at how to interpret the fact that older voters support Brexit while on the whole younger voters do not and how that will have changed overall support for Brexit as some of the older people die and younger people reach voting age. Is it really true that as people get older their political views tend to become more conservative and further toward the right side of the political spectrum? 
Or is this a myth? A few days ago we passed the date when, according to experts, the demographic turnover (coming of voting age and deaths) would have shifted the balance of the Brexit Referendum from the majority for Leave in June 2016 to a majority for Remain. This shift was based on the fact that Leave was a lot more popular among the over 65 year old voters than the under 25 year old voters, who were very strongly Remain supporters. In the two and half years since it was assumed that a lot more Leave voters had died than Remain voters, and a lot more young new voters would support Remain.  This crossover point was mentioned in political debates on TV, but was countered by the assertion that as people grow older their political views change i.e. the people who voted like 57 year olds in 2016 would vote like 60 year olds now, so in fact the passage of time since the referendum and the turnover of the voters would give the same outcome because the individuals would have changed their opinion as they got older.  So do people really become more conservative and right wing as they get older? Or does it only appear that they do, and that people's political views are more or less static and they only appear to have become more conservative or right wing because the average position of society has moved in the opposite direction?    For example society's view of gay rights, womens rights, universal healthcare, environmental protection, consumer rights, rates of taxation, paying for education etc have changed hugely over the last 50 years. So a 20 year old voter, 50 years ago who held views that were close to the left/right centre at that time, if they had kept the same views until now would be classed as an fairly extreme right wing conservative. So it would appear true that the voter had become more conservative and right wing, while it also being true that the voter had not changed their view at all, because it was society as a whole that had moved.  I am sure that some good quality study knows the answer, but I have not seen it, So is there evidence that on average people's politics move toward the right as they age, or do the people's views stay more or less fixed? Or is it more like sailing a boat that is moving through the water while the water is itself moving over the ground? So the person moves either to the left or right and at the same time society changes, so they can move left but finish up further right or vice versa.  So my question for any forecaster who has the answer is; is received wisdom correct that people become more conservative as they age? Something to chew on is that if older people are more conservative, and if conservative means "adverse to change", how is it that conservatives are identified  with Trump support in the US and Brexit support in the UK? When these seem to be examples of older so-called conservatives actually wanting radical changes (albeit to return to the past)?

It is highly unlikely that the Article 50 notification will be revoked. With May surviving the no-confidence vote, as well as the estimated 22 weeks it would take to hold another referendum, the Brexit move remains firmly on the table.
Now the question is; can the requisite negotiations take place before the 29 March deadline to make something happen? And will the EU budge on its conditions or reluctantly grant an extension? Though the EU has done their best to punish the UK for its decision throughout this entire process, ultimately their economies are too intertwined, which means they will likely grow slightly more lenient as the deadline approaches. Less likely yet still possible, the UK will continue to be plagued with deadlock and the deadline will ultimately make the decision for them. Ultimately, however, a bad plan is better than no plan, and an extension will be needed to properly implement.

I believe it is highly unlikely that the UK will revoke their notification of Article 50.  That would essentially invalidate the referendum that created BREXIT in the first place.  In order to revoke Article 50, they'd have to take another referendum or risk a constitutional crisis, and a second referendum does not guarantee a different outcome. An extension seems the most likely outcome.  However, it isn't as straightforward as it appears.  All 27 EU member countries have to agree to an extension, and the EU has elections scheduled in May.  Prior to the elections, the EU Parliament's BREXIT Steering Group will disband as new members are elected.  Unless Theresa May can come up with a viable "Plan B" (after her Plan A decisive failure and just-survived vote of no confidence last week) on short notice, an extension will be hard to come by.  The Guardian's editorial board suspects May is trying to "run down the clock" as she did in late 2018.  I suspect an 11th hour extension is the most likely scenario, but a lot has to fall into place to make it happen. The UK leaving the EU with no plan in place would prove disastrous for the economies of Europe, and the UK in particular.  The British Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond recently spoke with business leaders and explained that a "no-deal exit" is not on the table, but the government cannot go public with that information because it weakens their negotiating hand. The UK won’t revoke their submission of Article 50 without a new referendum.  I believe a new referendum is unlikely.
Extending Article 50 requires both UK and EU approval.  The EU sees the Brexit issue as a UK problem, and has been uncooperative in finding a resolution.  They are also unlikely to approve an extension unless they see a real tangible plan and not more of the “same ole, same ole.”
Because a referendum is unlikely, the EU is not helping the UK work out its own domestic problems, and that a “no deal” will be disastrous to UK, the government will come together to make a deal happen, even if it’s a bad deal.  
Justifications below:
May says Europe unlikely to extend Article 50; also says to do so would just prolong the Decision.   In regards to another referendum, May and other parliamentarians (including some opposed to Brexit) say that a new referendum breaks down society’s confidence in the government and “shatter faith in democracy” – the people voted, and you should do a re-vote because the outcome is difficult.  This leads me to believe that the government won’t allow a second referendum.  However, a new referendum could be used as a last resort after all other options are exhausted.  This is risky too because what if the new referendum results say “Yes, we the people still want Brexit?” and leaders have to consider that a referendum may not give them the answer they want.
Let the clock wind down until 29 March could cause huge economic uncertainty for the British; however next meaningful vote won’t be until early Feb.
Brussels says this is London’s decision, and they’re hands off.   Based on news since the Brexit vote, the EU has never been happy about the Brexit decision, and have seemed uncooperative in helping London get to a decision, making it seem unlikely that the EU would approved an Article 50 extension, even if that’s what the UK wants.  And an extension would require consent from all 27 member countries – 100% consensus on any issue is never easy.  But yet, Yvette Cooper, the chairwoman of the home affairs select committee, is planning to put down a tightly worded amendment to give time for a bill that would give parliament the power to support an extension of article 50.
Despite one of the worst defeats in Parliamentary history (voting down the Brexit deal), May survived a no-confidence vote.  To me this implies the government wants to get to a solution – working out a new government would be devastating in Brexit process.
Even the Britishers that don’t agree with May on her Brexit plans admire her grit and determination.

To be completely candid, I'm struggling to have a settled opinion on this forecast. A huge amount seems to hinge on how each of the EU27, Brussels and anti-no-deal UK Parliamentary majority respectively react under various scenarios, a lot of which depends on the sequencing of particular events.   Over the past few days my forecasting on the 'revocation' option particularly has wildly veered back and forth, as I consider whether sequencing scenarios X, Y or Z is most likely. This indecision disappoints me as I was hoping that getting into forecasting would help me enforce some mental rigour/decisiveness/clarity in committing to a distinct prediction (with all the risk-reward accountability that entails).  Unlike my other Brexit-related forecasts, I'm really not sure what I think about this question. So for the next few days I'm taking the coward's way out and will shadow the crowd consensus. Forecasting Brexit is a very challenging since Brexit is a complex problem.  Forecasting the question of “Before 30 March 2019, what will happen next with regard to the UK's notification of Article 50?” is affected by the day-to-day events since many of them are interrelated and affect the final outcome of Brexit.  I am having a hard time wrapping my head around them, especially when events happened that required updating the forecast. I have come up with a flow-chart with probabilities of individual events as placeholders (“Fermi-ize” the problem as described by Tetlock).  I use these placeholder values to calculate the probabilities for the forecasts.  It allows me to update the probabilities as circumstances change.  I am going to share this with you.  I am sure that I did not include everything.  Comments are welcome. Note on using/reading the flow chart:
The probabilities for each event is labeled in alphabets and enclosed in parentheses.  The formula for the calculated forecast probabilities use the alphabet labels.  One can substitute the label probabilities with actual numerical values of your forecasts (and updates) and compute the probabilities for the questions accordingly.   Parliament vote on 15 January
-----Yes (a) - leads to May-Brexit (i.e. the current negotiated Brexit plan)
-----No (b)
----------Leads to no-deal-Brexit – Probability (c)
---------------Overall probability = b*c
----------Or May asks for EU assurance on the Irish backstop – Probability (d)
---------------Overall probability = b*d
---------------Yes (e) – (EU provides assurance) – leads to another Parliament vote
--------------------Overall probability = b*d*e
-------------------------Yes (g) – May-Brexit with EU assurance
------------------------------Overall probability = b*d*e*g
-------------------------No (h) – request for Brexit delay from EU
------------------------------Overall probability = b*d*e*h
---------------No (f) - (EU does not provide assurance) – request for Brexit delay from EU 
--------------------Overall probability = b*d*f
--------------------Overall probability for request for Brexit delay = b*d*f + b*d*e*h                  
-------------------------No (j) – EU does not grant delay - leads to no-deal Brexit
------------------------------Overall probability = (b*d*f + b*d*e*h) *j
-------------------------Yes (i) – EU grants delay – leads to new referendum and/or new election
------------------------------Overall probability = (b*d*f + b*d*e*h) *i The Prediction Market leads heavily on the No for the 15 January vote.  I could use the current market predictions for the computation: a=3% and b=97%.  But I will forecast 100% for the No vote.  Therefore a=0% and b=100%.  If you use a value other than a=0%, you can update the rest of your probability using a=0 (assuming that it is the outcome). After the first vote, there is still time of more maneuvering.  A No-vote does not immediately lead to a no-deal Brexit.  May will definitely ask EU to provide assurance for the Irish backstop, and therefore c=0%, d=100%.   There are reports saying that EU is willing to provide the assurance after the first UK Parliament vote.  I put 75% probability for Yes (e) and 25% for No (f).  With assurance from EU, May will definitely ask for a second parliamentary note.  I put an even chance for passing the second parliamentary vote : g=50% and h=50%. If EU does not provide assurance or a No-vote for the second parliament vote, UK will definitely ask for a Brexit time extension.  We have to sum the two probabilities (for a time extension request) at this point. Right now, I put the probability of a time extension request to be 60 for Yes (i) and 40 or No (j).  If such an extension is not given, UK will exit with no-deal.  If there is an extension, there will be a potential second referendum and/or a general election. (To make it easier to do the computation, I am listing the values that I used:
a=0%, b=100;   c=0%, d=100%;   e=75%, f=25%;   g=50%, h=50%;   i=60%, j=40%) “Before 30 March 2019, what will happen next with regard to the UK's notification of Article 50?” 
 Using the probabilities shown above:
	UK exit (there are 4 paths including May-Brexit and no-deal Brexit) 
                    = a + b*c + b*d*e*g + (b*d*f + b*d*e*h)*j  
                    = 0 + 0 + 0.375 + (0.25+0.375)*0.4
                    = 63%
	Revoked by UK = 0%
	Extended by UK and EU 
                    =100-63 = 37%
                   (One can also calculate this probability using (b*d*f + b*d*e*h) *i, leading to the same 37%). As mentioned earlier, I will use this tool to update my forecast when changing situations.  You can try your hand on the computations using your own estimated probabilities for the individual events.

I've fundamentally changed my mind about the likelihood of a revocation (28% down to 1%) as I now cannot see how a sufficiently large Parliamentary coalition for this would emerge (especially given Labour's clear electoral conundrum and skittishness about making any commitment either way).   This would be the case even with a looming disorderly Brexit.   The unknown factor that gave me pause before revising this down is what the Government will do in the event of the Withdrawal Agreement failing to pass Parliament after multiple attempts - obviously the current position is a pre-vote posture and it remains to be seen how the Cabinet and PM would react.    Apart from extreme circumstances then it is hard to see how a revocation could be countenanced without a further referendum, for which there is no longer any time. The legal default is that the UK will Brexit at the end of March, whether or not a deal is agreed.   This remains the case even while all factions in Parliament now see it as in their interest to run down the clock.  For this reason, I still see it as by far the most likely outcome. (51% up to 61%) The only way for this to be averted is for Parliament to positively legislate for an alternate course, and (crucially) for this to also be agreed by the EU centrally and among the 27 member states.  I haven't seen much evidence yet that Parliament as a whole is ready to stop indulging its existential crisis, and suspect that their is quite a bit more mileage in their temporising on this issue.   Even if a new course were to be agreed by Parliament, a unilateral agreement from the UK's side would take time to ratify all around, so an extension would be necessary and (if it were a purely a case of implementation, and not just damage-limitation) then the EU's agreement would probably be forthcoming - however it is not yet clear whether there will even be enough time for an extension to be agreed in order for an alternative to be given time.   In many ways a non-commital decision to try to renegotiate would be the most inconclusive and tricky result, as it is not even clear that the EU would accept a return to the negotiating table, whatever their regrets about the consequences that would follow from a disorderly exit (this is why at this point I don't want to overrate the probability of an extension). Events will move rapidly particularly as we reach mid-January (late January is realistically the latest that a deal can be passed in Parliament to be ratified by the EU27 in time for March) when a number of the key contours will start shaping up and timing will be key over how the each probability will shift.   The use by all sides of the "timing out" to build pressure may potentially create a situation where the only way out of an impasse is to create more time, so I have boosted the probability of an extension (21% up to 38%), although still struggle to see the precise conditions that would allow this to happen, especially as it must be agreed by so many parties.

An extension of the grace period of A50 would produce a couple of hard to circumvent problems:
1) It would force an election for the European Parliament to be held in the UK
