A punt either way.  No way UK leaves EU while May is still in charge.

Its unlikely that May's Deal will be approved by Parliament as any one of four different groups who don't like her deal could vote against it and any one group would have enough votes to prevent the UK government passing the legislation. The four groups being; Hard Brexiteer (Conservatives), Hard Remain (Conservatives), Conservatives who are not happy that the "deal" contains no legally blinding framework for a Future Trade Deal (its only a Withdrawal Agreement), and the DUP. It  seems very unlikely that the government would get sufficient opposition MPs to vote for May's Deal to get it passed. 
Its extremely unlikely that  the parliament would allow the UK to just fall out of the EU with No Deal.
Therefore that leaves the possibilities of stopping Brexit by revoking A50 or extending it. Revoking A50 is technically the  easiest option because it does not require the EU to agree to it, it just needs the UK parliament to vote to Revoke. However Revoking A50 is politically much more difficult without parliament giving itself political cover by getting the UK public to agree by having a general election or referendum.
There is not sufficient time to have a referendum between now and 29th March, (it has been calculated that a referendum would take a minimum of 22 weeks) and even if there was time to hold the actual referendum some time after the referendum and before 29th March would be required to take any actions that were necessary after the result was known (if the result of a referendum was that the Brexit process should continue but not with May's Deal then A50 would need to be extended to allow for more negotiations.) 
Its possible that a General Election could take place, but assuming that it did, it almost certain that the Prime Minister would either be May or Corbyn. If it were May then nothing much would have changed. If it were Corbyn and he wanted to negotiate a different Brexit deal there would not be time to do it before 29th March (assume no General Election could be called before the second half of January, which would give Corbyn about 4 weeks to negotiate a deal with the EU and get it approved. That seems almost impossible.  The only possible deal I could see being done in that time would be to take May's Withdrawal Agreement, remove the Irish Backstop and replace it with a legally enforceable agreement that the UK will remain in the EEA and the Customs Union and will continue to contribute and obey EU rules and ECJ (i.e Norway+ Brexit).  
So extending A50 is by far the likely outcome.
My interpretation of MPs comments and polling results (particularly the recent YouGov polls as interpreted by Peter Kellner) is that many Leave voters and most Brexit supporting MPs are losing confidence that any Brexit that resembles the version promised before the June 2016 referendum will ever be possible. Brexit was sold as having cake (a frictionless trade relationship with the EU) and eating it (being able to do FTAs with 3rd countries, without allowing EU citizen Freedom of Movement, without paying subs to the EU, and without having to follow the ECJ rulings). After two and half years of the EU telling the UK that to have frictionless trade you have to be a member of the EU (or EEA+ Single Market), which requires that you abide by EU rules including the Four Freedoms, pay contributions and follow rulling of the ECJ, even the Brexiteers are starting to realise the EU is not kidding. And most of the Brexiteers know full well that without frictionless trade much of the UK's manufacturing industry (the part that depends on trans-European supply chains) would migrate into the remaining EA (that's a much bigger market than the UK).  While the Brexiteers favorite economist says that losing manufacturing is not a problem and that the UK could adjust, the Brexiteers are wondering how long it would take for this adjustment to happen (towns that lost their heavy manufacturing in the 1980s are still depressed now) and how the Leave voters will feel when they lose their jobs and are told to adjust. Leave voters are, I think, seeing that Brexit might be a great idea and a poke in the eye to the liberal elite, but the people that are likely be worse off are the left behind in the industrial towns, and maybe the elite (in the shape of the toffs who told them to vote Leave) have screwed them again.
No one wants to admit they were wrong, so I think the Leave voters and the Brexiteer MPs are desperately hoping that someone else will stop Brexit, so they don't have have admit they were wrong voting to Leave. If someone else stops Brexit then the Brexiteers (and Leave voters) will be able to say that Brexit would have been a wonderful thing if only traitors had not stopped them getting the deal they imagined.

1. Revoking Art. 50 means staying in the EU. It is so risky an action for the UK executive to undertake that it is politically impossible. It would almost certainly require a parliamentary vote and would cause a constitutional crisis. Only pro-EU extremists would do this - and they are too far from political power to do so. See: https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-cancel-stop-revoke-article-50-explained-remain-stay-eu-latest-parliament-theresa-may-a8690886.html
2. Exending Art. 50 would be very difficult and would split, and severely weaken, governing Conservative Party. Current political dynamics and preparations be EU and UK government make extension of current arrangements after UK formally leaves and continuing negotiations much more likely if no WA ratified by UK Parliament. A vote in Parliament would almost certainly be required to extend Article 50. See:
https://constitution-unit.com/2018/09/20/could-article-50-be-extended-to-allow-for-a-second-brexit-referendum/

Revoke - likelihood may increase with longer timescale, but difficult to see how this could be possible politically within this timeframe as no strong push for this within Parliament at present time (though Frances Grady of TUC recently has been calling for the "cancellation" of article 50).  Extend - looking increasingly possible, given no clear parliamentary majority for any form of Brexit or alternative at the present time. EU would not be keen for this to drag on, and potential complications around EU Parliament elections scheduling of May 2019 (should UK send/elect MEPs if still technically a member of EU under an extension?) may mean this is not seen as a desirable option.  Neither/UK leaves - While current withdrawal agreement/political declaration may be voted down in January, and there is no majority in Parliament for 'no deal'; could the EU still pull some last minute concessions/clarifications/legal guarantees out of the woodwork that convinces MPs to pass it at a second or third time of asking?
As is increasingly true always and everywhere, the smart move is the least likely.

REVOKE
There's zero chance of a parliamentary majority for revoke at the moment. Too many MPs are uncomfortable with directly contradicting a referendum. However, further down the line if May loses the vote in January then more MPs would support the idea and it starts to become a realistic possibility. For example if we asked to extend article 50 but the EU decided that it has us by the short-and-curlies and could force us to revoke by refusing to extend, then there would be a clamour for revoke. (As a Brexiter myself, this is quite an attractive option because being forced by the EU to choose would further strengthen anti-EU feelings not just in the UK but across Europe.) EXTEND
Theresa May will almost certainly lose the "meaningful vote" in January which will almost certainly lead to Brexit being extended. Some in the media are saying it's impossible for her to win that vote but I think she does have a slim chance. Although there's zero chance of the DUP voting yes (from their perspective, the unknown is preferable to a guaranteed disaster) and zero chance of the SNP voting yes, some Tory MPs will support her because of loyalty to their party or because they are scared of possible alternatives, and a handful of Labour MPs could also vote yes. But on the whole, DUP + SNP + LibDem + Labour + Tory hard Brexiters will almost certainly be a bigger number than Loyal / Scared / Pragmatic Tories + Labour rebels.
If, as looks likely, she loses, her deal is finally dead and buried, and then all hell breaks loose (again). We will have to start looking at alternatives, but the country has not done the necessary preparation to leave with no deal, there's not enough time to cobble together an alternative deal, and there still probably won't be enough support for revoking Brexit (but more than at the moment). So the only pragmatic solution is to extend. NEITHER / LEAVE
This bucket covers three possibilities, all of which are unlikely;
• Leave with Theresa May's deal: In the unlikely event that she gets her deal through parliament, we will probably leave the EU on that basis.
• Leave with another deal hurriedly put together: I don't see how Theresa May could do this herself given how tightly bound politically she is to her deal, and there isn't enough time for a new leader to be chosen then a new deal negotiated.
• Leave with no deal: I don't think Theresa May has the guts carry out her threat to do this, it would have to be someone else, and leaving with no deal would require preparation, which hasn't been done and there isn't time to do.
